awd_titl_txt: CSBR: Ownership Transfer: Rescue of two orphaned yeast collections
awd_abstract_narration:
The Phaff Yeast Culture Collection at the University of California Davis is used for basic research on yeast physiology, yeast ecology (especially yeast-insect associations), comparative genomics, and taxonomy, including discovery of new yeast species.  Yeast collections are also used for applied research, including study of food and beverage fermentation, food spoilage, biofuels exploration, and the development of improved methods to identify yeasts that cause human infections.  This award will fund the transfer of two existing collections, the Starmer collection from Syracuse University and the Ganter collection from Tennessee State University.  The Phaff Yeast Culture Collection is the fourth largest public yeast collection in the world, with over 7000 strains.  A total of 4000 yeast strains will be transferred to UC Davis, expanding the size of the Phaff collection by 50 percent.  In addition, the project staff participate in an annual UC Davis Biodiversity Museum Day, which attracts visitors to the yeast exhibits to learn about microbiology and societal benefits derived from yeasts and culture collections.

In this project, the Starmer and Ganter collections will be shipped to UC Davis where they will be cryopreserved, re-identified by ribosomal sequencing, archived off-site, added to the Phaff collection database, and DNA sequences will be deposited in GenBank.  All three collections include numerous undescribed species, and in some cases, the only known representatives of certain species. Geographically and taxonomically diverse yeast collections like this are now virtually impossible to re-collect.  Once the transfer is complete, the combined collection will be available to the global scientific community.  By posting DNA sequences of accessions in GenBank and expanding information available on the Phaff collection online catalog (http://phaffcollection.ucdavis.edu), the collection will be more visible and valuable for all users.

por.por_cntn:
The aims of this project were to transfer two orphaned yeast collections of retiring professors to the Phaff Yeast Culture Collection at UC Davis. Yeast ecologists William T. Starmer of Syracuse University and Phil Ganter Tennessee State University each accumulated collections of over 2,000 yeasts, collected in the course of research on yeast ecology, including expeditions funded by 26 NSF awards between 1974 and 2006. The collections are particularly valuable because the strains also carry extensive physiological characterization data painstakingly collected in the era before ribosomal sequencing was used for species ID. These data, which are no longer routinely collected, are particularly useful for correlating genotype and phenotype. The strains were isolated from numerous countries in North and South America, the Caribbean. Nagoya Protocol legislation in many of these countries now make it much more difficult to build this type of geographically diverse collection.

 

Phaff collection policies, which are based on OECD Best Practices Guidelines and other applicable regulations, require that yeast strains be pure, viable, and identified to species level before they can be used in research. Therefore, the most important aim of this project was correct species identification of the yeast strains. 

 

Activities completed:

In spring 2016, Starmer’s oiled agar slants at Syracuse University were inventoried, sorted, oil drained, repackaged to comply with shipping regulations, and shipped to UC Davis. Ganter’s lyophilized stocks were packaged and shipped, and inventoried. Viability and purity were tested, and a total of 2600 strains from both collections met these quality criteria, which met expectations stated in the proposal. Pure and viable strains were identified by ribosomal sequencing. 

  • Total number of yeast species in the addition: 119
  • Number of undescribed species: at least 42
  • Number of species not previously represented: 12

 

Lab data sheets and field notebooks were scanned. Geographic origin and host habitat (i.e. plant or insect species it was isolated from) were located in Starmer’s and Ganter’s field books and data sheets, and databased. Physiological characterization data (40 to 60 descriptors per strain) for 1,084 viable, pure strains were entered in the database. The remaining data are being located and entered.

 

Over 1,500 strains so far have met the criteria to be added to the public catalog (phaffcollection.ucdavis.edu) and also to the WFCC Global Catalog of Microorganisms (gcm.wfcc.info): they are pure, viable, identified to species, the species ID by ribosomal sequencing is consistent with the original species ID by Starmer or Ganter, and the species is not a known pathogen. 

 

New uses of Starmer and Ganter strains

Strains have already been used in several research projects in the Boundy-Mills research lab, including a USDA-funded project studying yeasts able to accumulate oil and secrete glycolipids that are natural surfactants. The collection rescue project, plus use of the ribosomal sequence data to circumscribe yeast species in the Sporopachydermia cereanacomplex was presented at the International Specialized Symposium on Yeast in Bariloche, Argentina in 2018. 

 

Broader impacts: 

Phaff collection personnel have participated in several public outreach activities to share knowledge about yeast, the Phaff collection, and research using the collection including Starmer and Ganter’s strains. 

  • 500 to 800 visitors of all ages visited the yeast displays at the annual UC Davis Biodiversity Museum Day in February 2016 - 2020. They learned about microbes, yeast, and the yeast collections through hands-on activities, displays, and guided tours of the teaching winery and brewery. Visitors learned about the rescue of the endangered Starmer and Ganter yeast collections. The visitors particularly enjoyed talking with real scientists, learning about cutting edge research at the Phaff collection and 11 other biodiversity collections at UC Davis, and seeing (and smelling) dozens of different species of yeast.
  • In January 2020, Phaff collection curator Kyria Boundy-Mills took over duties writing stories about culture collections for the US Culture Collection Network blog (usccn.blogspot.com). 
  • Boundy-Mills is serving on a committee of about 12 individuals associated with biological collections to write an NSF-funded report about the current status, uses, potential, and needs of U.S. biological collections.
  • In April 2017, a display about yeast and the Phaff collection was visited by over 900 members of the general public at UC Davis Picnic Day. 
  • In June 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016 and 2017, middle school students learned about yeast in a half-day unit on microbiology as part of UC Davis Bio Boot Camp, a 5-day summer day camp. 
  • The collection contributed display and educational materials for events put on by UC Davis STEM for Girls and the California Academy of Sciences.
  • Planned outreach events in spring 2020 at the Exploratorium science center (San Francisco) and UC Davis Museum of Entomology were postponed due to the COVID-19 crisis. 
  • The Phaff collection staff regularly respond to emails and phone calls from home bakers and brewers, commercial wineries and breweries, biotechnology companies, and the general public with questions about yeast.
